subject: Sleep
title: Alarm Clocks vs Natural Waking
description: A short lesson to help you apply Alarm Clocks vs Natural Waking.

hook.text: Before alarm clocks, a knocker-upper walked the streets tapping on windows with a long pole. That was your alarm.

buildup.text: The mechanical alarm clock was patented in 1847, just as factories demanded precise start times.

discovery.text: For most of history, humans woke naturally with the sun. Forced waking is an industrial invention.

twist.text: Alarm clocks often interrupt deep sleep or REM, causing sleep inertia and grogginess that natural waking avoids.

climax.text: If you need an alarm clock to wake up, you're not getting enough sleep. The alarm is a symptom, not a solution.

punchline.text: Alarm clocks don't wake you up. They interrupt your sleep.

quiz.question: What was a knocker-upper?
options: A person who tapped on windows to wake workers before alarm clocks
